item.title: 'Deeply disturbed': Angry fans vandalise stadium as Messi's India tour turns into chaos

item.description: A new study by Australian and Canadian archaeologists proves what our ancestors really ate: everything.

item.title: Why Sara and Issam still can't go to Cronulla beach 20 years after the riots
item.description: Australia's racial discrimination commissioner is warning that the factors that fomented the Cronulla riots are still in play today - and that a similar racial brawl could occur again.

item.title: Mary gave birth to her son in Australia. But he has no valid legal status
item.description: There's a growing number of undocumented children in regional Australia, born to disengaged migrant workers who have no visa.

item.description: While a motive is still unclear, police have revealed fresh details about the pair who mounted the terror attack at Bondi Beach.

item.description: There's one supermarket where a basket of groceries is significantly cheaper than its competitors, according to a new survey.

item.description: The Opposition will instead prioritise the formation of an antisemitism and counter-terrorism taskforce.

item.description: One of the many heroes who sprang into action after Sunday's attack says "now, more than ever, we need each other".

item.title: I have never earned more money, but I've never felt more broke
item.description: Chris Booy works three jobs. Despite this, he says that the Great Australian Dream of owning a home is feeling increasingly out of reach.

item.description: Donald Trump appears to be ramping up pressure on Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro, whom he called "illegitimate".

item.description: Two flags linked to the self-proclaimed Islamic State group were found in the car used by the alleged shooters during Sunday's attack at Bondi Beach.

item.title: Government deficit figure has improved, but fiscal restraint important
item.description: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has unveiled a mid-year budget update marked by fiscal restraint, highlighting a $5.4 billion improvement to the deficit alongside critical new funding for the CSIRO and community security. However, the outlook remains fraught as rising inflation threatens real wage growth and persistent spending pressures in childcare and the NDIS continue to squeeze the bottom line.

item.title: How does your day compare? Here's how Australians are spending their time
item.description: Almost 10,700 Australians were surveyed, revealing both insights and disparities in daily life.

item.description: Misinformation and disinformation have been circulated widely since Sunday's massacre.

item.description: As part of its response to the Bondi Beach attack, which claimed 15 lives, the government will review its migration settings.

item.title: Terror at Bondi, Fragile Hope in Ukraine & Trump’s ‘WMD’ Gamble
item.description: Terror strikes the iconic sands of Bondi Beach, sending shockwaves through Australia and Jewish communities worldwide - how did the deadly attack unfold, and what does it mean for national security? Plus, Volodymyr Zelenskyy signals cautious optimism in high-stakes Ukraine peace talks but is a deal with Russia any closer? And Donald Trump brands fentanyl a ‘weapon of mass destruction’ as tensions escalate with Venezuela.

Fears of further financial pain for Australians after major banks' forecasting

item.description: Experts share how to keep cool this summer — smart home hacks, indoor greenery and safe spots for your pets, without breaking the bank.

item.description: The decision followed hours of discussions among leaders on the technical details of an unprecedented loan based on frozen Russian assets.

item.description: Levi Xu was forced to make a choice: either face the risk of being shot, or drown.

item.title: 'Huge range of emotions' spill out as Allegra Spender targeted in tense exchange at Bondi
item.description: The independent MP was fiercely criticised by a man in Bondi who accused her of failing to do enough to combat anti-Jewish hate.

item.title: 'We're changing lives': This small Sydney bakery gave Ben more than a job
item.description: At a small bakery in Sydney, asylum seekers and refugees find more than work — they find hope, belonging and a chance to rebuild their lives.

item.description: The ‍Syrian government fully supported the United States' strikes against IS group targets in Syria, US President Donald Trump said.

item.description: Some Pakistani Australians say the false identification of one of the alleged Bondi attackers has had a serious impact on their lives.

item.title: From fringe to frontline: How Australia's far right gained mainstream attention in 2025
item.description: From extremist fringes to the Senate, the far-right opportunistically dug their claws into Australian society and discourse this year.

item.title: What is Denmark's not-so-secret recipe for happiness?
item.description: Denmark has been ranked among the 'happiest' countries in the world for more than a decade. Some experts suggest this is due to a focus on learning compassion, empathy and human connection at an early age, which supports positive inter-personal relations and conflict resolution in adulthood.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Can early education make your children happy adults?
item.description: Jessica Joelle Alexander is a parenting expert, author and cultural researcher, with a specific expertise in the Danish parenting approach. Alexander is also the co-founder of 'Raising Digital Citizens', which aims to support families to have conversations around values in the online space. Denmark has been ranked among the 'happiest' countries in the world for more than a decade and a big part of this ranking has been linked to learning empathy from a young age. Her books and research explores this concept - and how parents can foster compassion, resilience, emotional-intelligence and human connection from an early age.

item.title: Jamie followed his dad's 14,000km England-to-Australia bike ride — here's how it went
item.description: Jamie Hargreaves retraces his father's 1984 journey from England to Australia, adapting the route across Europe and Asia.

item.title: PM orders review into federal police and intelligence agencies after Bondi terror attack
item.description: The review will examine whether the agencies "have the right powers, structures, processes and sharing arrangements in place".

item.title: 'Under-16 refugees': Will this platform see another new wave of users after the social media ban?
item.description: With under-16s now excluded from many of their favourite social media apps, alternative platforms remain available, especially for bilingual teens.

item.description: The quiet pastime of birdwatching is taking flight online, linking enthusiasts beyond the outdoors.

item.description: The powerful storytelling of culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) writers is on full display in SBS' first summer reading guide.

item.description: For some people who have experienced life-threatening situations, it's not the situation itself that has the longest-lasting impact — it's the aftermath.

item.description: Israel said the 19 newly approved settlements are located in what it described as "highly strategic" areas.

item.title: Predictable policies and shock results: looking back at 2025 in politics
item.description: For Australian politics in 2025, it was a year of predictable policies - and shock results. That included the May election that saw Labor win back government in a landslide, and two separate party leaders - Peter Dutton and Adam Bandt - lose their seats. We back at the year in Canberra.

item.title: US coast guard in 'pursuit' of another oil tanker near Venezuela
item.description: The first oil tanker was seized by US forces on 10 December and a second one was "apprehended" on 20 December.

item.description: While throuples are becoming more common and those in them say they can work, experts warn they can be tricky.

item.title: 'A part of the US': Trump appoints Greenland envoy, sparking diplomatic backlash
item.description: The US move revives sovereignty fears in the Arctic, as Denmark and Greenland warn strategic interests cannot justify territorial claims.

item.title: Australia in 2025: The events that shaped the nation
item.description: It has been a turbulent 12 months for Australians with unity in the community tested with the spillover of tensions from global conflicts. There was also milestone moments with the trial of mushroom cook Erin Patterson, and the ongoing impact of climate-driven weather extremes.

item.title: Capped numbers, shorter licences: How gun laws are set to change in NSW
item.description: NSW parliament has passed new firearms legislation in the wake of the Bondi Beach terror attack.

item.title: Albanese recommends changes to MP travel perks following expenses controversy
item.description: Families of politicians would have their flights downgraded to economy class if the recommendations are implemented.

item.title: NSW parliament passes laws limiting protests, but will they be allowed to stand?
item.description: Laws to restrict the right to protest in New South Wales after the Bondi terror attack have passed the Parliament after a marathon sitting. A broad coalition of groups has expressed strong opposition, characterising the reforms as overreach and a serious threat to democracy. A constitutional challenge has been announced but the government is standing firm, setting the stage for a High Court challenge.

item.title: Double demerits: What are the holiday road rules in place in your state?
item.description: In some parts of Australia, double demerits have arrived.

item.title: US, Venezuela edge closer to serious confrontation
item.description: The United States and Venezuela are edging closer to a serious diplomatic confrontation, after the US seized two oil tankers linked to the Venezuelan government in international waters, with a third now under pursuit. Venezuela accuses the US of piracy and an illegal naval blockade, as pressure mounts on the country's already sanctioned oil industry, with both Iran and China stating matters could spiral out of control.

item.title: This country has been crowned the world's 'happiest' for decades. Experts reveal why
item.description: Some experts suggest Denmark's happiness success is due to a focus on learning compassion, empathy and human connection at an early age.

item.description: Severe storms threaten Queensland, Melbourne will be cool and WA braces for extreme heat and bushfire warnings on Christmas Day.

item.description: What's open this holiday season? Supermarket, retail, liquor, bank and medical trading hours across Australia.

item.title: Turning points: what defined the world in 2025
item.description: 2025 has been a huge year for geopolitics, natural disasters and a changing of the guard at the top levers of international power and influence. We look back at the key moments.

item.description: While mainstream Jewish organisations have welcomed Isaac Herzog's recently announced visit to Australia, others have expressed dismay.

item.description: The news comes after a South African man had his visa cancelled in November for taking part in a neo-Nazi rally.

item.description: An Aboriginal legal service in the NT will launch a challenge to laws it says undermine fundamental legal principles.

item.description: Around the world, and in migrant communities across Australia, a diverse range of customs give Christmas a unique flavour.

item.description: Christmas can be a challenging time for some. These groups are working to bring community to those who need it.

item.description: The US-backed proposal stops short of recognising seized territory as Russian, though future Ukrainian withdrawals remain on the table.

item.title: A heroine, a monster and true love - the new genre that's overturned the book world
item.description: It's not science fiction, but it has elements. It's not romance, but it touches the heart. It's not fantasy but don't be surprised if you encounter a werewolf or an elf. It's the new literary craze which is taking the book world by storm, driven by millions of fans on the social media platform TikTok. It's called romantasy.

item.title: The full beauty of Lake St Clair's depths is revealed
item.description: Lake St Clair is surrounded by Tasmania's Wilderness World Heritage area and was carved out by glaciers over millions of years. It's around twice as deep as Bass Strait, but Australia's deepest lake has never been fully mapped. Until now: CSIRO scientists have produced the first 3D map of the underwater landscape, confirming the vast depth of the natural wonder.

item.title: How to safely store your Christmas leftovers and avoid food poisoning
item.description: If your Christmas feast has finished and you see large portions of food untouched on your table, you might only have a couple of hours to keep them.

item.title: 'Evil presence': PM condemns suspected antisemitic firebombing of a car in Melbourne
item.description: Detectives in Melbourne are investigating a suspicious antisemtic fire on Christmas Day.

item.title: Ready for take-off? Here's how international travel is changing in 2026
item.description: From fresh international routes to new digital identity requirements, here's what you need to know about heading overseas next year.

item.title: Burnt out from 2025? Here's how to actually rest over the break
item.description: December can be a stressful time of year, and not everyone returns to work refreshed after the festive season.

item.title: 'Shared longing for peace': King Charles praises Bondi heroes in Christmas message
item.description: King Charles has spoken about overcoming uncertainty and division in his annual Christmas address.

item.description: In an address from the balcony of St Peter's Basilica, the pontiff also called for an end to conflicts in Ukraine, Sudan, Thailand and Cambodia.

item.title: The hidden workforce behind Melbourne’s tram seats
item.description: Melbourne’s trams have been part of the city for more than 140 years. Almost half a million people ride them each day — but few know the story behind the seats they sit on.

item.description: New NBN data reveals how streaming, working from home and faster broadband are reshaping Australia's internet usage.

item.description: Australians are expected to spend more on Boxing Day sales this year. Here's how to take

item.title: Refugee hotline sees spike in calls for help after Bondi terror attack
item.description: A hotline supporting refugees who have fled war, violence and persecution has received a funding boost after the Bondi terror attack. Those running the hotline service in New South Wales says the funding will allow it to extend its reach nationally, supporting refugees as they navigate the ongoing effects of complex trauma and triggers of what happened at Bondi.

item.description: A daily news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Have an hour to spare these holidays? It could make a big difference to your retirement
item.description: Many Australians don’t know their super balance or how it’s invested — and the super industry says the holidays are a good time to change that.

item.title: Trump says he ordered strikes against IS in Nigeria
item.description: President Donald Trump says the United States has launched a 'powerful and deadly' strike against IS in north-western Nigeria. Mr Trump described those killed as 'terrorist scum' who had been targeting and killing primarily innocent Christians.

item.title: Another election, 'no winner'? What’s at stake in Kosovo's snap vote
item.description: The Balkan country is headed to the polls on Sunday, after nearly a year of political deadlock that's caused "colossal damage" to its economy.

item.title: From the White House to the Vatican: A year of global turning points
item.description: Here's a look at 2025, shaped by global events — from political shifts to natural disasters — defining a year of change and challenge.

item.title: As the housing crisis worsens, this city hotel is helping to build homes for at-risk women
item.description: .Raising funds to ease homelessness among women is the focus of a Sydney hotel, one of 12,000 social enterprises in Australia that combine profit with purpose.

item.title: Russia hits Ukraine with drone, missile strikes ahead of Zelenskyy-Trump meeting
item.description: Before the overnight attacks, the Ukrainian president said the talks would focus on the territorial aspects of a proposed peace deal.

item.title: New developments and old battles: Australia's health year in 2025
item.description: As with most years, the health sector has been a constant source of news stories - from outbreaks of illnesses to outstanding medical research, from politics to pandemics, from injuries to infections. SBS news looks back at some of the medical stories that hit the news in 2025.

item.title: Two dead in alleged Palestinian ramming and knife attack in Israel
item.description: It comes a day after an Israeli reservist allegedly rammed his vehicle into a Palestinian man as he prayed on a roadside in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: Elusive wild cat thought to be extinct rediscovered in Thailand after 30 years
item.description: Flat-headed cats are among the world's rarest and most threatened wild felines, with the last documented sighting in Thailand in 1995.

item.title: How a hostel set up over 100 years ago is still helping to change women's lives
item.description: A century-old women's hostel has evolved, but it's continued its mission of supporting housing for women.

item.title: How changing our safety signs could save lives every summer
item.description: Experts are warning that Australia's beach warning signs do not clearly convey the message to those who do not speak English as a first language.

item.title: 'Guerrilla rewilding': The people controversially fighting to restore near-extinct animals
item.description: Rewilders around the world have sought to reintroduce species to their traditional habitats. But not all efforts have official approval.

item.title: Inside Australia's rental crunch — and what the numbers say about 2026
item.description: As summer listings rise, a tight supply and strong demand keep affordability pressures high. Here's what's next for the rental market in 2026.

item.title: What are Australians reading? The book genres Australians are loving the most
item.description: As the holiday season hits there's nothing like grabbing a good book, heading to a cool shady spot and reading a story that takes you into another world. But with so many digital distractions, how popular are books and what genres are catching readers' interest the most? Please note: This story contains sexual references.

item.title: How young birdwatchers are taking flight in the digital age
item.description: .When you think of birdwatching, retirees probably come to mind. But a new generation is picking up binoculars and taking on the hobby. What was once an escape from the online world is making a comeback online.

item.title: Myanmar goes to polls after five years of civil war. Here's how the junta-run vote will work
item.description: The military has framed the votes as a return to democracy, but experts and rights groups say the military is "engineering an outcome".

item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has met with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and European leaders ahead of his crucial meeting with Donald Trump.

item.description: Here are the latest capital-city weather forecasts from the Bureau of Meteorology.

item.title: Cyclone Alfred among top ten costliest climate-change-linked disasters of 2025
item.description: Economic losses caused by the fierce storm that ravaged southeast Queensland and northern NSW clocked in at roughly $1.8 billion.

item.title: Minns vows to keep 'racist' preacher's venue shut, flags new security plans
item.description: The premier flagged the possibility of deploying the army to protect Jewish institutions and arming a Jewish community security organisation.

item.description: It's important to factor in your age, income and financial goals when making an investment plan.

item.description: Australians collectively have more than $4 trillion in superannuation. However, some question whether the system is truly benefiting them.

item.description: Brigitte Bardot was propelled into international stardom when she played a teen bride in the 1956 movie And God Created Woman.

item.description: The two leaders met at Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida for talks on ending the war in Ukraine.

item.description: The military junta said the election would bring political stability to Myanmar, despite rights groups saying the vote was neither free nor fair.

item.title: REPLAY: Belonging Nowhere: Fadi was born in Lebanon - but technically, he didn't exist
item.description: Belonging nowhere is a reality for millions of people around the world: it's known as statelessness. Described by some as an overlooked human rights issue, this first episode delves into the history of statelessness and who stateless people are.

item.description: As governments tighten rules on e-mobility devices, experts say policy gaps remain in keeping young people safe on the roads.

item.description: Sydneysiders can expect extra security around official celebrations this year, which will include a tribute to the Jewish community.

item.title: How to turn your unwanted Christmas gifts into someone else's treasure
item.description: If you've been handed a gift for Christmas that just doesn't tick the right boxes for you, it might just be the perfect item for someone else.

item.description: Proposed reforms would expand whistleblower protections, but advocates say they don't go far enough.

item.title: Search resumes for MH370 more than a decade after it went missing
item.description: The search for Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 is set to resume more than a decade after the aircraft vanished while travelling from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing with 239 people on board. A fresh search in the southern Indian Ocean is being conducted by private marine robotics company Ocean Infinity, using advanced technology in hopes of retrieving answers to one of the world's greatest aviation mysteries. But families of passengers on board say they need transparency on the terms of the search, and clarity on the prospects for recovery.

item.title: Tim hopes a treechange will help him save a house deposit. He's not alone
item.description: Young Australians are moving to remote or regional Australia to fast-track their savings. But is it worth the sacrifice?

item.title: From international students to skilled visas: Inside Australia's 2026 migration shift
item.description: Australia enters 2026 with an unchanged migration cap, tighter skilled priorities, more student places and reforms triggered by the Bondi attack, but experts say issues remain.

item.title: Trump warns of possible Iran strike, urges Hamas to disarm after meeting Netanyahu
item.description: Trump said he still believed Iran was still interested in a deal with the US on its nuclear and missile programs.

item.title: China Launches Military Drills Around Taiwan | Morning News Bulletin 30 December 2025
item.description: China launches major military drills around Taiwan; the search resumes for Malaysia Airlines flight MH370; Alex de Minaur’s bid to beat Carlos Alcaraz and Jannik Sinner.

item.title: Ukraine denies attacking Putin's residence, calls allegations 'lies' to undermine peace talks
item.description: Russian foreign minister said Ukraine had fired "91 long-range unmanned aerial vehicles" at President Vladimir Putin's residence in the Novgorod region.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Feyza Tuncay on helping children learn about ethics
item.description: Primary Ethics is an independent, not-for-profit organisation and provides ethics classes for school students across New South Wales. Classes are impartially run by volunteers and the program has been implemented in hundreds of schools. Facilitator Feyza Tuncay became involved with Primary Ethics when she started volunteering as an ethics teacher at her son's school. She's speaking here to SBS News' Jennifer Scherer.

item.title: Man dies in Qld floodwaters; 'destructive' cyclone makes landfall in WA
item.description: A man in his 70s was found dead in a submerged vehicle in north-west Queensland on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: REPLAY: Belonging Nowhere: How hard is it to feel like you belong in Australia?
item.description: Many stateless people are displaced around the world, attempting to find somewhere they can call home. Their journeys can often take a heavy toll, as they deal with traumatic experiences, or need to hid their true identities as a persecuted minority. In this second episode of 'Belonging Nowhere' we’ll hear some of the many stories of how people from different stateless backgrounds come to Australia – and the difficulties they’ve faced trying to make a home.

item.title: Two killed in boxer Anthony Joshua crash identified as 'close friends and team members'
item.description: The two fatalities were identified as Joshua's close friends.

item.title: Fairfield West man charged over plan to carry out public shooting | Midday News Bulletin 30 December 2025
item.description: Fairfield West man charged over plan to carry-out public place shooting; Trump threatens military action against Iran as Netanyahu visits Mar-a-Lago; And in cricket, Todd Murphy tipped for recall as Australia rethink spinner strategy for Ashes finale.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 30 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Bangladesh's first female prime minister Khaleda Zia dies at 80
item.description: Khaleda Zia was seen as a frontrunner to win the February 2026 general election in Bangladesh.

item.title: Russia accuses Ukraine of attacking Putin residence
item.description: Russia has accused Ukraine of trying to attack President Vladimir Putin's residence in northern Russia, which Ukraine's government has dismissed as baseless and designed to undermine peace negotiations. The angry exchanges have dealt a new blow to prospects for peace in Ukraine.

item.title: From farm lit to romantasy: How Australian reading habits changed in 2025
item.description: From true crime to the rise of 'single dad' fiction — these are the reads Australians couldn't get enough of in 2025.

item.title: Donald Trump confirms land strike on Venezuela | Evening News Bulletin 30 December 2025
item.description: Sussan Ley continues to push for a royal commission into the Bondi terror attack; Donald Trump confirms land strike on Venezuela in possible escalation of military operations; And in football, ticket requests for the 2026 World Cup break FIFA records.

item.title: Precious metals pull back & investment themes for 2026
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Gemma Dale from nabtrade about the day's sharemarket action and a look to the investment themes for 2026.

item.title: Police reveal new details on alleged Bondi shooters as inquiries get underway
item.description: More details have emerged from police into the motives and movements of the two alleged shooters of the Bondi Beach terror attack. An initial assessment has found Sajid and Naveed Akram acted alone, and weren't part of a terrorist cell.

item.title: 'I was called a dirty Muslim': Fears of a 'surge in hate-driven incidents' after Bondi attack
item.description: Australian Muslim leaders have issued a public plea to warn of an "alarming surge" of attacks against members of the community who they say are unfairly being blamed for the Bondi Beach terror attack.

item.title: What to know about China's major military drills around Taiwan
item.description: The military exercises are believed to be some of Beijing's largest to date.

item.title: Anthony Albanese and Sussan Ley reflect on Bondi terror attack in New Year's messages
item.description: In their New Year's addresses, the prime minister and Opposition leader delivered a strong message of hope, courage and unity.

item.title: How Olympic boxer Harry Garside shifted his mindset around masculinity
item.description: We hear from Australian men who are figuring out what it means to be a man in an evolving contemporary context.

item.title: Tax, super, childcare, medicines and more: Your cheat sheet to big changes in 2026
item.description: From tax cuts to payday super, a number of changes are coming for Australians across childcare, household budgets and medicines.

item.title: Israel to halt operation of more than 30 Gaza aid organisations
item.description: Israel says it will suspend several humanitarian organisations for failing to meet its new rules to vet international organisations working in Gaza.

item.title: Year ends with wild weather | Morning Bulletin 31 December 2025
item.description: Tropical Cyclone Hayley hits WA as a man dies in Queensland floods; Israel suspends more than 20 aid agencies operating in Gaza; Overall honours upset looms in the Sydney to Hobart.

item.title: Why are students and shopkeepers demonstrating across Iran?
item.description: Iran's economy, already battered by decades of sanctions, was further strained after the UN in late September reinstated international sanctions.

item.title: UAE to pull remaining forces from Yemen as crisis deepens following Saudi airstrike
item.description: A Saudi-led coalition says it has targeted shipments of weapons and combat vehicles in Yemen that were unloaded from vessels coming from the UAE.

item.title: Why predicting bushfires this summer has been 'particularly tricky'
item.description: A weaker La Niña and an unusual warming high above Antarctica are pulling Australia's weather in opposite directions, experts say.

item.title: Anthony Albanese delivers his New Year's message | Midday News Bulletin 31 December 2025
item.description: Anthony Albanese delivers his New Year's message, Iran accuses Israel of destabilising the Middle-East; and in cricket, Damien Martyn in an induced coma following a meningitis diagnosis.

item.title: Why this Australian K-pop star is being sued for $44 million in South Korea
item.description: The company behind hit K-pop group NewJeans has filed a lawsuit against one of the group's members, marking the latest development in a long-running dispute.

item.title: 'Get well Marto': Cricket world gets behind Damien Martyn after sudden hospitalisation
item.description: Damien Martyn has been put in an induced coma amid a bout of meningitis, according to reports.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 31 December 2025
item.description: A daily 5 minute bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Australia gears up to bring in a 2026 of hope
item.description: Sydney's iconic New Year's Eve fireworks will ring in 2026, but celebrations will look a little different this year with some police officers carrying long-arms following the Bondi terror attack. In other cities the New Year will also be welcomed with fireworks and music in many popular spots around the country.

item.title: Russia deploys nuclear-capable missiles to Belarus
item.description: Russia says nuclear-capable missiles have been deployed to Belarus and are in active service. It brings the weapons closer to Europe as Russia toughens its negotiating position in peace talks with Ukraine.

item.title: Australians prepare to enjoy the New Year’s Eve fireworks | Evening News Bulletin 31 December 2025
item.description: Australians prepare to enjoy the New Year’s Eve fireworks; aid groups condemn Israel's suspension of their operations in Gaza; and in sports, a new overall winner named in the Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race.

item.title: The year that was on the ASX and the year ahead
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Mark Gardner from MPC Markets about whether investors should be happy with the near 7% return on the ASX200 this year and what the key investment themes for 2026 will likely be.

item.title: In pictures and videos: These were the moments that defined 2025
item.description: A look back at the images and moments that defined Australia and the world in 2025.

item.title: Aid agencies in Gaza condemn Israel's suspension of their licences to operate
item.description: The Israeli government is set to revoke the licences of 37 aid groups working in Gaza and the West Bank, which have failed to meet its new vetting rules. Israel says the suspensions will not affect the delivery of aid, but the move has drawn widespread criticism.

item.title: China responds to Australian criticism of military drills, Taiwan still on high alert
item.description: Australia said on Wednesday that China's military drills around Taiwan were "deeply concerning, destabilising and risk inflaming regional tensions".

item.title: A childhood erased: Abducted by her mother and raised as a missing person
item.description: After being abducted, Rose was forced to spend her childhood living under a false identity and trying to evade police.

item.title: The advice this Howard-era immigration minister would give to Sussan Ley
item.description: Philip Ruddock, the father of Australia's controversial asylum seekers policy, says the Opposition shouldn't fixate on numbers.

item.title: 'Casualties should be anticipated': Howard warned on sending elite soldiers to Afghanistan
item.description: Declassified documents reveal what John Howard's cabinet considered, and ignored, when sending troops to Afghanistan.

item.title: Australians ring in 2026 with a focus on peace and unity
item.description: New Year's Eve revellers have had a moment of silent reflection for the Bondi victims before enjoying brilliant firework displays across the county.

item.title: Australians celebrate the start of 2026 | Morning Bulletin 1 January 2026
item.description: Australians celebrate the start of 2026, Racist flyers found in letterboxes in Newcastle, Team Canada and China's tennis stars visit a Sydney zoo ahead of their United Cup campaign.

item.title: Disasters, defence and pandemics: what the cabinet papers reveal about 2005
item.description: Hundreds of newly released cabinet papers reveal the inner workings of the Howard government in the mid-noughties with warnings about the role that defence personnel should play in Afghanistan and Australia's preparedness for a pandemic.

item.title: Should artificial intelligence be used in job recruitment?
item.description: The use of AI in recruitment is on the rise, with almost two thirds of Australian organisations believed to be using the technology in their job hiring processes. There are growing concerns over the risks of discrimination.

item.title: In pictures: World bids goodbye to 2025 with fireworks, light shows and icy plunges
item.description: People all over the world are ringing in the new year with traditions old and new.

item.title: Trump says national guard troops being pulled from Chicago, LA and Portland
item.description: Trump said in a social media post that federal forces will "come back" if crime rates go up.

item.title: The World welcomes a New Year | Midday News Bulletin 1 January 2026
item.description: People around the world usher out 2025, embracing 2026 with hope, Woman drowns, man missing in New Year’s Day surf incidents at Sydney beaches, Matildas captain Sam Kerr celebrates New Year’s Eve with wedding to partner Kristie Mewis.

item.title: Israeli military kills man in West Bank, UN condemns utilities cut to Palestinian refugee agency
item.description: The Israeli military killed a man in the occupied West Bank on Thursday. Separately, the UN has criticised Israel's ban on supplying water or electricity to UNRWA facilities.

item.title: 'Weak agreements only fuel the war': Zelenskyy says Ukraine ready for a 'strong peace'
item.description: "Are we tired? Very. Does ‍this mean we are ready to surrender? Anyone who thinks so is deeply mistaken," Zelenskyy said in his New Year address.

item.title: PM again defends decision on royal commission after Bondi attack | Evening News Bulletin 1 January 2026
item.description: Anthony Albanese again defends the decision not to call a national royal commission into the Bondi terror attack, newly released cabinet papers from 2005 reveal government decision-making on national security; Australia's T20 World Cup squad announced.

item.title: Albanese rejects human rights commissioner's call for Bondi royal commission
item.description: The prime minister has continued to resist calls for a royal commission into the Bondi attack after a new voice joined the chorus appealing for one.

item.title: Government 'disappointed' with China's new beef import tariffs
item.description: An industry group has also warned the newly announced tariffs could damage trade worth over $1 billion between Australia and China.

item.title: Australian man reportedly killed while fighting in Ukraine
item.description: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade said it was seeking to confirm the reported death with authorities in Ukraine.

item.title: Dakar Rally 2026 nears as Aussie champ Daniel Sanders eyes 'back-to-back' wins
item.description: The 48th edition of the Dakar Rally kicks off this weekend in Saudi Arabia. Here's what to know about the gruelling motor race.

item.title: Power, pirate flags and political upheaval: How youth-led protests spread across borders
item.description: From Kathmandu to Manila, 2025 became a year when streets pushed back. Youth-led protests challenged corruption, demanding accountability.

item.title: Dozens killed, Australian among more than 100 injured in Swiss ski resort New Year's fire
item.description: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade said it was making urgent enquiries with local authorities to determine whether any other Australians were impacted.

item.title: Dozens killed in a fire at a Swiss ski resort | Morning News Bulletin 2 January 2026
item.description: Dozens killed in a fire at a Swiss ski resort; Australia's beef industry set to be hit by new Chinese tariffs; And in tennis, Ash Barty urges Australian stars to capitalise on home summer ahead of Open.

item.title: Trump says US will intervene if Iran 'violently kills' protesters after reports of six deaths
item.description: Protests in Iran that started over high rates of inflation and a fall in the currency have led to several deaths, Iranian media reports say.

item.title: REPLAY: Belonging nowhere: Stateless in Australia
item.description: While statelessness affects millions of people around the world, Australia also has stateless people.The United Nations refugee agency says there are around 8,000 stateless people in Australia, but experts say there could be more. The UNHCR is calling on the Australian government to create a stateless determination procedure (SDP), which would contribute to efforts to assess the size and the situation of stateless population amongst migrant populations.The fourth episode of Belonging Nowhere looks at Australia and how it deals with statelessness.

item.title: 'I put myself out there': Khawaja calls stumps on international career with message to critics
item.description: Khawaja said he'll forever carry the memories, friendships and "lessons that shaped me".

item.title: Crowd chants 'tax the rich' as Zohran Mamdani sworn in as first Muslim mayor of New York
item.description: Mamdani, a self-described democratic socialist, comes to power at a time when Trump has pushed a hard-right agenda.

item.title: Tragedy in Switzerland as fire rips through a resort bar | Midday News Bulletin 2 January 2026
item.description: Tragedy in Switzerland as fire rips through a resort bar, A safety warning for beachgoers after a spate of drownings, Usman Khawaja announces his retirement from international cricket.

item.title: Resort fire on NY Eve one of Switzerland's deadliest disasters
item.description: A New Year’s Eve celebration at a luxury Alpine ski resort has ended in one of the deadliest disasters in Switzerland's modern history. Around 40 people are dead and more than 100 injured, including one Australian, after a fire tore through a crowded nightclub in the early hours of New Year’s Day, triggering scenes of panic, chaos and devastation. A warning: this story has elements that may distress some people.

item.title: Tragic fire claims lives in Swiss bar | SBS News in Easy English 2 January 2025
item.description: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

item.title: Amid rising military pressure, Venezuela's Maduro says he's open to dialogue with the US
item.description: The Venezuelan government has neither confirmed nor denied Donald Trump's claim of a US strike on a "dock area where they load the boats up with drugs" in Venezuela.

item.title: Why Usman Khawaja's influence went far beyond the cricket pitch
item.description: From advocating for representation to speaking out on Gaza, Usman Khawaja's influence reaches well beyond the boundary — with many Australians viewing him as "a symbol of resilience and inclusion".

item.title: China reimposes taxes on condoms, contraceptive drugs to spur flagging birth rate
item.description: China's population fell for a third consecutive year in 2024 and experts have warned the downturn will continue.

item.title: Concerns over China's surprise new beef tariffs | Evening News Bulletin 2 January 2026
item.description: Concerns over China's surprise new beef tariffs, New financial incentives for apprenticeships, Brisbane Lions Lachie Neale steps down as club co-captain

item.title: Multiple drowning deaths in 'horrendous' start to 2026
item.description: Three deaths have been confirmed in NSW and Queensland, with two people missing and feared dead.

item.title: China's New Year surprise: hefty new tariff on beef exports exceeding quota
item.description: Australia’s billion-dollar beef trade faces a massive shakeup as China imposes a new 55 per cent tariff on imports that exceed strictly capped annual quotas. While the Chinese government claims the move will protect its farmers from oversupply, Australian industry leaders and the Federal Opposition warn the tariff increase breaches the spirit of Australia's long-standing free trade agreement with China.
